text: I'd have to say that my experience with HP workstations has been quite different. One of the reasons that I like them is that they're so well put together and I've never had problems with cooling even if I max them out for hours at a time, the quality of the cases is way beyond normal consumer equipment and I've never had a problem with a power supply, fan or anything like that. I should stress that I'm talking about high end used hardware though, the sort of things that come out of professional video studios or labs, so they're made to be reliable.

attachments.title: The tax free nature of gambling proceeds
attachments.text: HMRC was sceptical of an individual’s explanation of his £300k income being derived from the tax-free pursuit of gambling activities. The tax tribunal supported his appeal against the tax assessments and provided some valuable reminders in its judgement.
attachments.fallback: RSM UK: The tax free nature of gambling proceeds

elements.text: I presume I can get betfair records from the dawn of time If I email and request them, this person for some reason could not prove it, seems kinda dodgy.

text: Betfair can give you a summary (monthly totals and lifetime P&L) but probably not a record of every single bet going back decades. I suggest people keep a good record of this themselves - what bet you placed on what and how much you won and lost - and this should obviously corroborate with what comes out into your bank account.

text: I've been routinely using the API to obtain all my bet records on the horses since April this year. Before that just have monthly per market stuff. Not sure what the time interval on these things is but I can still query results at a market level (not bet level) per strategy reference going back a year (not tried beyond that).

text:
Sort of on this subject, there are some scenarios that come up and I'm curious how other people go about this:

1. Orders don't appear to settle properly at market level. So this appears to result in the orders settling correctly at bet level when the market closes, but when calling listClearedOrders at the market level it doesn't exist (this normally appears to get fixed after a couple of days, but it occasionally does drag on longer).
2. A market gets settled, all appears to be correct, but then Betfair re-settle at a later date.
Both are fairly uncommon, but do occur occasionally, I'm just wondering if there is any way to detect if a market is re-settled, or is it simply a case of calling listClearedOrders periodically and doing a lookback (and presumably taking settled bets with the most recently settled time if a bet with the same id already exists in my DB)?

I'm guessing it is the latter, but just wanted to be sure.

elements.text: Sort of on this subject, there are some scenarios that come up and I'm curious how other people go about this:

Orders don't appear to settle properly at market level. So this appears to result in the orders settling correctly at bet level when the market closes, but when calling listClearedOrders at the market level it doesn't exist (this normally appears to get fixed after a couple of days, but it occasionally does drag on longer).
A market gets settled, all appears to be correct, but then Betfair re-settle at a later date.

Both are fairly uncommon, but do occur occasionally, I'm just wondering if there is any way to detect if a market is re-settled, or is it simply a case of calling listClearedOrders periodically and doing a lookback (and presumably taking settled bets with the most recently settled time if a bet with the same id already exists in my DB)?

I'm guessing it is the latter, but just wanted to be sure.

text:
For no. 2, I do call listClearedOrders periodically grouping by market level and order level, there's also comparison between the two to make sure totals match in the db.
Regarding your first point, I never found any solution for this. I do have a list where orders vs market don't match or did not settle completely but after a while I kind of stopped caring.

elements.text:
For no. 2, I do call listClearedOrders periodically grouping by market level and order level, there's also comparison between the two to make sure totals match in the db.
Regarding your first point, I never found any solution for this. I do have a list where orders vs market don't match or did not settle completely but after a while I kind of stopped caring.

text: I've never noticed these things but that is probably because I pull them only on a monthly basis and just use my own logs in the interim. That way I hope to avoid missing out on any incorrect settlements etc.

elements.text: I've never noticed these things but that is probably because I pull them only on a monthly basis and just use my own logs in the interim. That way I hope to avoid missing out on any incorrect settlements etc.
